descript.abstract: This coverage and associated databases contain data from selected fields of five tables in the MAS/MILS database. This database was transferred to the U.S. Geological Survey from the U.S. Bureau of Mines upon its closure in 1996. The database is considered archival and will be incorporated into the U.S. Geological Survey mineral location database along with the MRDS database.
descript.purpose: To provide searchable mineral locations for the U.S. Geological Survey Spatial Data Delivery Website.

timeperd.current: Date of extraction of data from MAS/MILS database.

status.update: In year 2000 if changes are made in the database or additional information is requested.

idinfo.useconst: None. Acknowledgement of the U.S. Geological Survey would be appreciated.

cntperp.cntorg: U.S. Geological Survey, Spokane Field Office

idinfo.datacred: Data from MAS/MILS database, U.S. Geological Survey
idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows Vista Version 6.0 (Build 6001) Service Pack 1; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.3.0.1770

citeinfo.title: Deposit Information Manual and Data Dictionary

dataqual.complete: Contains all locations in MAS/MILS database as of time of download.

srcinfo.srccontr: Previous repository for the data presented here.

procstep.procdesc: Selected fields were extracted from the MAS/MILS database using and SQL query. The information in the DLAT and DLON fields was used to create an Arc/Info coverage (mas_sdd) using the GENERATE command. The SEQ field was attached to the .pat feature attribue table using the JOINITEM command. The information in all the ArcInfo tables were then turned into .dbf (dBASE) format to create the mas1.dbf, name.dbf, state.dbf, commodity.dbf, and bib.dbf files. All tables except the state.dbf are linked by the SEQ field. The state.dbf links to the mas1.dbf by the combination of STA and COU fields to form a unique join. An ArcView shapefile called masmil.shp was created from the original ArcInfo coverage (mas_sdd). All of the dbf files, except the state.dbf, can be joined to the masmil.shp using the seq field as the relate key.

enttyp.enttypd: Mineral locations in an ArcView shapefile format

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

edom.edomvd: Any name can be used here.
Property in production at time of information
Previously operating mineral property, now abandoned.
Mineral prospect or claim without workings.
Status other than one of the above.
Main entrance to a mine, usually the main portal.
Nearest town used if mine location not known.
Center of open pit or prospect pit.
Used when other categories aren't correct.

attr.attrdef: Precision of point location in meters
U. S. Geological Survey topographic map name

edom.edomvd: Any valid U.S. Geological Survey topographic map

attr.attrdef: Scale of map list in MAP field
Type of public or private Domain

edom.edomvd: Property contains more than one surface estate.
Ocean and lake bottom claimed by state.
Ocean bottom claimed by United States.
Public land under Bureau of Land Management.
Ocean bottom not claimed by a government.
Mineral rights leased from the Federal Government.
Mineral rights leased from State Government.
Mineral rights leased from private owner.
Mineral rights owned, but not surface.
Ownership not one of other categories.

attr.attrdef: U. S. Geological Survey Mineral Resource Data System (MRDS) number

edom.edomvd: location information with validity confirmed through investigation by evaluator,

edom.edomvd: mineral land assessment (MLA) project was done
no MLA project (or database wasn't coded - this is true more often than not)

distinfo.distliab: The U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) provides this data as is. The USGS makes no guarantee or warranty concerning the accuracy of information contained in the data. The USGS further makes no warranties, either expressed or implied as to any other matter whatsoever, including, without limitation, the condition of the product, or its fitness for any particular purpose. The burden for determining fitness for use lies entirely with the user. Although this data has been processed successfully on computers at the USGS, no warranty, expressed or implied, is made by the USGS regarding the use of this data on any other system, nor does the fact of distribution constitute or imply any such warranty.
